21.q: Who does Job want to pay for the guilt of the wicked person?

21.a: No, for he judges even those who are high.
They both lie down alike in the dust and the worms cover them both.
21.q: What happens to both the man who dies in full strength and the one who dies in bitterness of soul?

21.a: He knows their thoughts and the ways in which they wish to wrong him.
21.q: What does Job know about his friends' thoughts and ways?

21.a: They have seen that the wicked man is kept from the day of calamity, and that he is led away from the day of wrath.
21.q: What have traveling people seen happen to the wicked man?

21.a: Men will keep watch over his tomb.
21.q: What will men do for the tomb of the wicked man?

21.a: Job says Zophar was comforting him with nonsense.
21.q: With what does Job say Zophar was trying to comfort him?

22.a: He asks if it brings any pleasure to the Almighty if Job is righteous.
22.q: What does Eliphaz ask Job if his righteousness can do for the Almighty?

22.a: He mockingly says that because Job was reverent to God, he rebukes Job.
22.q: How does Eliphaz mock Job's reverence for God?

22.a: He says that Job has stripped the naked of their clothing.
22.q: What does Eliphaz accuse Job of doing to the naked?

22.a: He claims Job has sent widows away empty.
22.q: What does Eliphaz accuse Job of doing to widows?

22.a: He says that there is darkness, so that Job cannot see.
22.q: What does Eliphaz say the darkness has done to Job?

22.a: Job says, "Thick clouds are a covering to God, so that he does not see people."
22.q: What does Eliphaz claim Job says about God not seeing people?

22.a: The wicked men's foundations have washed away like a river.
22.q: What happens to the foundations of wicked men?

22.a: The righteous see their fate and are glad.
22.q: How do the righteous act when they see the fate of the wicked?

22.a: If Job is at peace with God, good will come to him.
22.q: What will happen if Job is at peace with God?

22.a: If Job returns to the Almighty, he will be built up.
22.q: What does Eliphaz say will happen if Job returns to the Almighty?

22.a: When Job takes pleasure in the Almighty, he will lift up his face to God.
22.q: What will happen when Job takes pleasure in the Almighty?
What does God do to the proud?

23.a: Job said that his suffering is heavier than his groaning.
23.q: What does Job say is heaveir than his groaning?

23.a: He would lay his case in order before God and fill his mouth with arguments.
23.q: What would Job do before God if he could find him?

23.a: No, he thinks God would pay attention to him.
23.q: Does Job think God would against him in the greatness of God's power if he could stand before him?

23.a: Job says in the south, God hides himself so that Job cannot see him.
23.q: What does Job say God is doing in the south?

23.a: When God has tested Job, he will come out like gold.
23.q: What result does Job expect from God's testing him?

23.a: Job has treasured up in his heart the words of God's mouth.
23.q: What has Job done with the words of God's mouth?

23.a: God carries out his decrees for Job.
23.q: What does God carry out for Job?

23.a: When Job thinks about him, he is afraid of him.
23.q: How does Job feel when he thinks about God?

23.a: The thick darkness cover's Job's face.

24.a: Job asks why times for judging the wicked are not set by the Almighty.
24.q: What times does Job think are not set by the Almighty?

24.a: They drive away the donkey of the fatherless.
24.q: What do the wicked do to the donkey of the fatherless?

24.a: They hope the Arabah will provide them food for their children.
24.q: What do the poor hope the Arabah will provide?

24.a: They have no covering in the cold.
24.q: What do the poor lack in the cold?

24.a: They embrace a rock for lack of shelter.
24.q: What do the poor embrace for lack of shelter?

24.a: Even though they go hungry, they carry others' sheaves of grain.
24.q: What do the poor do for others even though they go hungry?

24.a: They tread the wicked men's winepresses, but they suffer thirst.
24.q: What do the poor do for others even though they suffer thirst?

24.a: In the night, the muderer is like a thief.
24.q: What is the murderer like in the night?

24.a: The wicked do not care for the light.
24.q: Why do the wicked shut themselves up in daytime?

24.a: They are comfortable with the terrors of the thick darkness.
24.q: With what terrors are the wicked comfortable?

24.a: Sheol consumes those who have sinned.
The wicked one devours the barren women who have not born children.
24.q: Who does the wicked one devour?

24.a: God drags away the mighty by his power.
In only a little while, the mighty will be gone.
24.q: What will happen to the mighty in a little while?

25.a: God makes order in his high places of heaven.
He asks if one who is born of a woman can be clean and acceptable to God.
25.q: Of whom does Bildad ask can they be clean and acceptable to God?

25.a: He says that a son of man is a worm.
25.q: To what does Bildad compare a son of man?

26.a: No, Job wants to know who helped Bildad speak his words.
26.q: How does Job think Bildad's spoke his own words?

26.a: Destruction itself has no covering against God.
26.q: What has no covering before God?

26.a: He binds up the waters in his thick clouds.
26.q: Where does God bind up the waters?

26.a: He encloses the face of the moon and spreads his clouds on it.
26.q: What does God spread on the face of the moon?

26.a: He calmed the sea with his power.
26.q: What did God calm with his power?

26.a: By his breath, he cleared the heavens of storms.
26.q: By what did God clear the heavens of storms?

26.a: We hear but a small whisper of him.
26.q: What measure of God's voice do we hear?

27.a: God has taken away his justice.
27.q: What does Job say God has taken away from him?

27.a: Job vows that surely his lips will not speak unrighteousness.
27.q: What does Job vow his lips will not speak?

27.a: His thoughts will not reproach him so long as he lives.
27.q: How long will Job's thoughts not reproach him?

27.a: When God cuts off his life, God takes away his soul.
27.q: What does Job say God does when he cuts off a godless man's life?

27.a: Job said that he would not conceal the thoughts of the Almighty.
27.q: What does Job say he will not conceal of the Almighty?

27.a: His offspring will never have enough food.
27.q: Of what will the wicked man's offspring not have enough?

27.a: His widow will make no lament for him.
27.q: What will the wicked man's widow not do for him?

27.a: The innocent will divide up his silver among themselves.
27.q: What will happen to the silver of the wicked man?

27.a: He opens his eyes, and everything is gone.
27.q: What does the wicked man see when he opens his eyes after he lies down rich?

27.a: The east wind carries him away, and it sweeps him out of his place.
27.q: What does the east wind do as it carries the wicked man away?

27.a: He tries to flee out of its hand.
27.q: What does the wicked man try to do when the east wind does not stop?

28.a: Copper is smelted out of the stone.
Man searches out, to the farthest limit, the stones in obscurity and thick darkness.
28.q: What does man search out to the farthest limit?

28.a: He breaks open a shaft away from where people live.
28.q: Where does man break open a shaft?
What is contained in the dust of the earth?

28.a: The proud animals have not walked such a path, nor has the fierce lion passed there.
28.q: What has not walked through the path of man's shaft?

28.a: His eye sees every valuable thing there.
28.q: What does man see in the channels he cuts among the rocks?

28.a: Both of these are not found in the land of the living.
28.q: Where are wisdom and understanding not found?

28.a: Gold and crystal cannot equal both of these in worth.
28.q: What cannot equal the worth of wisdom and understanding?

28.a: The price of wisdom is more than rubies.
28.q: The price of wisdom is more than what jewel?

28.a: Wisdom is hidden from the eyes of all living things.
28.q: From whose eyes is wisdom hidden?

28.a: God understands the way to wisdom and he knows its place.
He parceled out the waters by measure.
28.q: What did God parcel out by measure?

28.a: He made a decree for the rain.
28.q: For what did God make a decree?

28.a: To people God said, "See, the fear of the Lord—that is wisdom."
28.q: What did God tell people is wisdom?

29.a: Job remembers that in the past months God had cared for him.
29.q: Does Job recall a time when God cared for him?

29.a: Job remembers the ripeness of his days, when the friendship of God was on his tent.
29.q: What was on Job's tent in the ripeness of his days?

29.a: When the almighty was with Job, the rock poured out for him streams of oil.
29.q: What had the rock poured out for Job in the past?

29.a: They saw Job and kept their distance from him in respect.
29.q: How did the young men show respect for Job in the city square?

29.a: They used to refrain from talking when he came.
29.q: What did the princes do in the past when Job came?

29.a: Their tongue clung to the roof of their mouths.
29.q: What happened to the tongue of the noblemen when Job came?

29.a: They would then give witness to Job and approve of him.
29.q: What would the noblemen do after their eyes saw Job?

29.a: He caused her heart to sing for joy.
29.q: What did Job cause the widow's heart to do?

29.a: He would examine the case even of one whom he did not know.
29.q: What had Job done even for the person he did not know?

29.a: He plucked the victim out from between the teeth of the unrighteous.
29.q: Who would Job pluck from the teeth of the unrighteous?

29.a: The bow of his strength is always new in his hand.
29.q: What does Job say is always new in his hand?

29.a: They opened their mouth wide to drink in his words as they would for the latter rain.
29.q: What did men wait to drink in like rain from Job?

29.a: He say that he is like one who comforts mourners at a funeral.
29.q: To what does Job compare himself at a funeral?

30.a: Those who are younger than Job have nothing but mockery for him.
30.q: Who has nothing but mockery for Job?

30.a: They were thin from poverty and hunger.
30.q: What made the young men's fathers thin?

30.a: Their fathers were driven out from among people.
30.q: From where were the young men's fathers driven out?

30.a: Job says that they were descendants of fools, indeed, of worthless men.
30.q: Of whom does Job say the young men's fathers are descendants.

30.a: Job had become their subject for a song of mockery.
30.q: What had Job become for the sons of the worthless men?

30.a: These people lose all self-control in front of him.
30.q: What do the people now lose in front of Job?

30.a: They push forward disaster for him, for they have no one to hold them back.
30.q: Why are the men able to push forward disaster for Job?

30.a: His honor is driven away as if by the wind.
30.q: What does Job say is driven away by the wind?

30.a: Many days of suffering have laid hold on him.
30.q: What has laid hold of Job as his life is pouring out within him?

30.a: God's great force has seized my clothing.
30.q: What does Job say has seized his clothing?

30.a: God has changed and become cruel to him; with the power of his hand God persecutes him.
30.q: How does Job say God persecutes him as he has changed and become cruel?

30.a: He knows that God will bring him to death, to the house destined for all living things.
30.q: What does Job know is destined for all living things?

30.a: When he waited for light, darkness came instead.
30.q: What came when Job waited for light?

30.a: He stood up in the assembly and cried for help.
30.q: Where did Job stand to call for help?

30.a: Job says that his harp is tuned for songs of mourning.
30.q: For what kind of music does Job say his harp is tuned?

31.a: Job has made a covenant with his eyes to not look with desire on a virgin.
31.q: What desire does Job say is subdued by a covenant with his eyes?

31.a: Job used to think that calamity was for the unrighteous.
31.q: For whom did Job use to think calamity was reserved?

31.a: He asks to be weighed in an even balance, so that God would know his integrity.
31.q: What does Job ask to be done so that God would know his integrity?

31.a: He says to let the harvest be uprooted out of his field.
31.q: What does Job ask to happen to the harvest, if he has turned out of the right way?

31.a: Job says to let his wife grind grain for another man.
31.q: What does Job say should be the judgement if he was attracted to another woman?

31.a: Job says that it is a fire that consumes everything for sheol.
31.q: What kind of fire does Job say this crime is like?

31.a: God made and molded them all in the womb.
31.q: What did God do for both the servants and for Job?

31.a: He says the orphan grew up with him as with a father.
31.q: How does Job say he has treated the orphan from his youth?

31.a: They should have been warmed with the wool of his sheep.
31.q: What should be offered to warm the needy with no clothing?

31.a: Job says to let his shoulder fall from the shoulder blade.
31.q: What part of his body does Job say should come off if he has failed to have compassion?

31.a: They could say to fine gold, "You are my confidence."
31.q: What could people say to fine gold?

31.a: If he worshiped them he would have denied the God who is above.
31.q: Who would Job be denying if he worshipped the sun or moon?

31.a: Job has not suffered his mouth to sin by asking for the life of those who hate him with a curse.
31.q: How has Job not suffered his mouth to sin?

31.a: He had always opened his doors to the traveler.
31.q: What had Job always done for the traveler?

31.a: He has hidden his sins by hiding his guilt inside his tunic.
31.q: How does Job say mankind has hidden his sins?

31.a: Job desired the indictment that his opponent had written.
31.q: What does Job want to have that his opponent has written?

31.a: He would go up to him as a confident prince.
31.q: How would Job go up to his opponent if he had their indictment?

31.a: Job said to let thorns grow instead of wheat and weeds instead of barley.
31.q: If Job has caused landowners to lose their lives, what does he call to grow instead of crops?

32.q: What did Job's three friends do when they could not convince Job that he had done anything wrong?

32.a: Elihu's anger was kindled against Job.
32.q: What emotion was kindled in Elihu when Job continued to justify himself rather than God?

32.a: He was angry with Job's friends because they had found no answer to Job and yet they had condemned Job.
32.q: Why was Elihu's anger kindled against Job's three friends?

32.a: Elihu was young and the others were all very old and should be able to teach wisdom.
32.q: Why was Elihu timid and afraid to tell Job and his friends what he was thinking?

32.a: The breath of the Almighty gives man understanding.
32.q: Who does Elihu say gives understanding to man?

32.a: It is not only the great who are wise, and it not the aged alone who understand justice.
32.q: Why does Elihu say the others should listen to him and allow him to declare what he knows?

32.a: Job's friends were not able to convince Job or respond to his words.
32.q: What were Job's friends not able to do even though Elihu waited for them to speak, and paid attention carefully?

32.a: It is God who must refute Job.
32.q: Who does Elihu say must refute Job when the three friends, who thought they were wise, were not able to do that?

32.a: Elihu decided that because the friends had not a word more to say, he will not wait any longer.
32.q: What does Elihu decide to do because the three friends were dumbfounded and could not answer Job?

32.a: The spirit compels Elihu to share his knowledge.
32.q: What is it that compels Elihu to share his knowledge with Job?

32.a: He says his breast feels like wine in new wineskins that are ready to burst.
32.q: What does Elihu say he is feeling like within his breast?

32.a: Elihu says that his Maker would soon take him away.
32.q: What does Elihu say his Maker would do to him if he were to speak and give honorific titles to any man?

33.a: Elihu begs Job to listen because he will speak the uprightness of his heart.
33.q: Why does Elihu beg Job to listen to the words he will speak?

33.a: The Spirit of God made Elihu and the Almighty gave him life.
33.q: Who has made Elihu and what has given him life?

33.a: He asks Job to set his words in order and stand up before Elihu.
33.q: What does Elihu ask Job to do if Job could answer Elihu?

33.a: Elihu tells Job that they are the same in God's sight and were both formed out of the clay.
33.q: What reason does Elihu give that Job should not be afraid of him or feel pressure from Elihu?

33.a: Elihu heard Job saying that he was clean, without transgression, innocent and there was no sin in him.
33.q: What had Elihu heard Job saying?

33.a: Job blames God for doing these things.
33.q: Who does Job blame for finding opportunities to attack him, and for regarding him as an enemy?

33.a: Elihu says God is greater than man.
33.q: How does Elihu say God compares to man?

33.a: God does not have to account for any of his doings.
33.q: Why does Elihu say it is useless to struggle against God?

33.a: God speaks in a dream and in a vision during the night while men are sleeping.
33.q: How does Elihu say that God speaks to man?

33.a: God does this in order to pull man back from sinful purposes and keep pride from him.
33.q: Why does God open the ears of men and frighten them with threats?

33.a: Elihu says that this is because man is being punished.
33.q: What does Elihu say is the reason that man has pain on his bed, agony in his bones, and no desire for food or delicacies?

33.a: A man's flesh is consumed, his bones stick out and his soul draws close to the pit.
33.q: What does Elihu say happens to a man who is being punished by God?

33.a: The angel could ay to God, "I have found a ransom for him."
33.q: What could an angel mediator say to God to save a person from going down to the pit?

33.a: His flesh will become fresher than a child's.
33.q: What will happen to the flesh of the person who is saved from going down to the pit?

33.a: That person's life will continue to see light.
33.q: What will happen to the life of a person who admits his sin and is rescued from the pit by God?

33.a: God does this so that a person may be enlightened with the light of life.
33.q: Why does Elihu say that God rescues a person from the pit?

33.a: Elihu wants to teach Job wisdom.
33.q: What does Elihu want to teach Job if Job will pay attention and listen to him and remain silent?

34.a: Elhu wants the wise men and those who have knowledge to listen to him.
34.q: Who does Elihu want to listen to his words and hear him?

34.a: Elihu wants them to choose what is just and discover what is good.
34.q: What does Elihu want others to choose and discover for themselves?

34.a: Job says that God has taken away his rights.
34.q: What does Job say that God has taken away from him even though he is without sin and what is incurable?

34.a: He says Job goes around in the company of those who do evil.
34.q: In whose company does Elihu say Job goes around?

34.a: God does not do wickedness, commit sin, or pervert justice.
34.q: What does Elihu tell the men of understanding that God does not do?

34.a: All flesh would perish and mankind would return to dust again.
34.q: What does Elihu say would happen if God ever gathered back to himself his spirit and his breath?

34.a: He implies Job is condemning God who is righteous and mighty.
34.q: Who does Elihu's question imply that Job is condemning?

34.a: Leaders, rich and poor, are all the work of God's hands.
34.q: Who does Elihu say are the works of God's hands?

34.a: Elihu says that God sees a person's ways and all his steps.
34.q: What does Elihu say that God sees.

34.a: God overthrows them in the night and they are destroyed.
34.q: What does God do in the night to mighty men whose ways and deeds he knows?

34.a: God will kill them in the open sight of others.
34.q: What will God do to those who do wicked deeds like criminals and make the cry of the poor come to him?

34.a: God rules over the nation and the individual alike.
Elihu suggests that Job should admit that he is guilty and has committed sin, but will do it no longer.
34.q: What is Elihu suggesting that Job should admit to God?

34.a: They will say that Job speaks without knowledge and wisdom.
34.q: What will men of understanding say about Job?

34.a: He says that Job is adding rebellion to his sin.
34.q: What does Elihu say Job is adding to his sin because of his talking like wicked men?

35.a: Elihu implies that Job thinks he is innocent, and that he is more righteous than God.
35.q: How does Elihu imply Job compares himself to God?

35.a: Elihu tells them to look up and see the sky.
35.q: What does Elihu tell Job and his friends to look up and see?

35.a: Job's wickedness could hurt a man and his righteousness could benefit another son of man.
35.q: What effect could Job's wickedness or his rightousness have on another man?

35.a: They cry out for help because of the many acts of oppression.
35.q: Why do people cry out for help from the arms of mighty men?

35.a: God gives songs in the night, teaches us, and makes us wise.
35.q: What things does Elihu say that God can do for people even though no one acknowledges it?

35.a: Elihu says that God does not give an answer when people cry out because of the pride of evil men.
35.q: Why does Elihu say that God does not give an answer when people cry out to him?

35.a: He will certainly not hear a foolish cry.
35.q: What will God certainly not hear?

35.a: He says Job opens his mouth to speak foolishness and to pile up words without knowledge.
35.q: What does Elihu accuse Job of doing when Job opens his mouth?

36.a: Elihu acknowledges that righteousness belongs to his Maker.
36.q: To whom does Elihu acknowledge that righteousness belongs?

36.a: He does what is right for those who suffer.
36.q: What does God do for those who those who suffer?

36.a: He sets them on thrones like kings forever, and they are lifted up.
36.q: What does God do for the righteous?

36.a: He reveals to them what they have done, their transgressions, and how they behaved arrogantly.
36.q: What does God reveal to those who are bound in chains and trapped in cords of suffering?

36.a: They will spend their days in prosperity and their years in contentment.
36.q: What will happen to listen to God and worship him?

36.a: They will perish by the sword and die because they have no knowledge.
36.q: What will happen to the people who do not listen to God?

36.a: They will die in their youth and their lives will end in disgrace.
36.q: What does the godless person who stores up anger and does not cry out to God for help?

36.a: God uses affliction to rescue the afflicted and oppression to open their ears.
36.q: How does Elihu say God uses affliction and oppression?

36.a: God would like to draw Job out of his distress into a broad place where there is no hardship.
36.q: What does Elihu say that God would like to do for Job?

36.a: He is full of the judgment on the wicked.
Wealth could lead Job to deception and a bribe could turn him aside from justice.
36.q: What things could lead Job to deception and turn him aside from justice?

36.a: Job's wealth and the force of his strength will not help him out of his distress.
36.q: What things will not be able to help Job out of his distress?

36.a: Job is being tested by suffering so that he will stay away from sinning.
36.q: Why does Elihu say that Job is being tested by suffering?

36.a: No one can say that God has committed unrighteousness.
36.q: What can no one say about God?

36.a: We cannot calculate the number of his years.
36.q: What is it about God that we cannot calculate?

36.a: He draws up the drops of water that distill as rain from his vapor, which the clouds pour down and drop in abundance on mankind.
36.q: How does God cause rain to fall?

36.a: He spreads lightning around himself and covers the sea with darkness in order to feed people and give food in abundance.
36.q: Why does Elihu say that God spreads lightning and covers the sea with darkness?

36.a: The noise of the lightning bolts hitting their targets tells people and cattle of the coming storm.
36.q: What tells people and cattle of the coming storm?

37.a: The noise of God's voice and the sound from his mouth causes Elihu's heart to tremble.
HE tells the snow to fall to the earth, and the rain to become a great shower of rain.
37.q: What does God tell the snow and the rain to do?

37.a: God stops them so that all people may see his deeds.
37.q: Why does God stop the hand of every man from working?

37.a: They hide and stay in their dens because of the storms that come.
37.q: For what reason do the beasts go into hiding and stay in their dens?

37.a: By the breath of God ice is given.
37.q: What is given by the breath of God?

37.a: He makes this happen sometimes for correction, sometimes for his land, and sometimes as acts of covenant faithfulness.
37.q: For what reasons does God give guidance to the clouds and cause them to do whatever he commands?

37.a: He wants Job to stop and think about God's marvelous deeds.
37.q: About what does Elihu want Job to stop and think?

37.a: God makes lightning bolts flash in the clouds.
37.q: What happens when God forces his will on the clouds?

37.a: He says the sky is as strong as a mirror of cast metal.
37.q: What image does Elihu use to describe the sky?

37.a: They cannot lay out their arguments before God because of the darkness of their minds.
37.q: Why does Elihu say that he and others cannot lay out their arguments before God?

37.a: People cannot look at the sun when it is bright in the sky.
37.q: What is it that people cannot look at when the sky is clear?

37.a: The Almighty does not oppress people.
37.q: What does Elihu say that the Almighty does not do to his people?

37.a: The Almighty does not pay attention to those who are wise in their own minds.
37.q: To whom does Elihu say that the Almighty does not pay attention?

38.a: Yahweh spoke to Job out of a fierce storm.
38.q: Out of what did Yahweh speak to Job?

38.a: Job brought darkness to Yahweh's plans by means of words without knowledge.
38.q: By what means did someone bring darkness to Yahweh's plans?

38.a: Job must gird up his loins like a man and answer Yahweh's questions.
38.q: What does Yahweh tell Job he must do when Yahweh questions him?

38.a: The morning stars sang together and all the sons of God shouted for joy when the cornerstone was laid.
38.q: What sang together and who shouted for joy when Yahweh laid the cornerstone of the earth?

38.a: God compares the sea bursting out of doors to coming out of the womb.
38.q: To what does Yahweh compare the sea bursting out after it was shut up with doors?

38.a: Yahweh put in place bars and doors to mark a boundary for the sea.
38.q: What did Yahweh put in place to mark out the boundary of the sea so that it could come only so far and no farther?

38.a: The light of dawn changes the earth so that all things on it stand out clearly like the folds of a piece of clothing.
38.q: How is the earth is changed in appearance like clay changes under a seal?

38.a: Yahweh mocks Job by saying that undoubtedly Job should know about this because the number of Job's days is so large.
38.q: What does Yahweh say to mock Job about his lack of knowledge about the way to the resting place of light and darkness?

38.a: Yahweh has kept these storehouses for times of trouble and for days of battle and war.
38.q: For what reason does Yahweh say he has kept storehouses for the snow and the hail?

38.a: He causes it to rain in order to meet the needs of the barren and lonely regions and to make the tender grass sprout up.
38.q: Why does Yahweh cause it to rain on the wilderness in which there is no person?

38.a: He asks Job if he can fasten chains on Pleiades or undo the cords of Orion.
38.q: What does Yahweh asks Job if he can do to Pleiades and Orion?

38.a: The dust runs into a hard mass and the clods of earth clump tightly together.
38.q: What happens to the dust and clods of earth when Yahweh pours out water on them?

38.a: They are crouch in their dens and shelter in hiding to lie in wait.
38.q: Where do the young lion cubs wait for their food?

38.a: They stagger about for lack of food.
38.q: Why do the young ones of the ravens stagger about?

39.a: They go out and do not come back again.
39.q: What happens to the young deer after they grow up in the open fields?

39.a: He has made his home in the Arabah, and his house in the salt land.
39.q: Where has Yahweh made the home of the donkey?

39.a: He roams over the mountains where he looks for every green plant to eat.
39.q: Where does the wild donkey find food?

39.a: He asks Job if with a rope, he can make the wild ox to plow the furrows or harrow the valleys for him.
39.q: What does Yahweh ask Job to make the wild ox do with a rope?

39.a: The wings of the ostrich wave proudly.
39.q: What does the ostrich wave proudly?

39.a: She leaves her eggs on the earth, and lets them keep warm in the dust.
39.q: What does the ostrich do with her eggs?

39.a: Yahweh has deprived her of wisdom and not given her any understanding.
39.q: Why does the ostrich not fear that her labor might have been in vain?

39.a: She laughs in scorn at the horse and its rider.
39.q: What does Yahweh say the ostrich does when she runs?

39.a: A flowing mane clothes his neck.
39.q: What clothes the neck of the horse?

39.a: He does not turn back from the sword.
39.q: How does the horse react to the sword?

39.a: He cannot stand in one place.
39.q: What can the horse not do at the sound of the trumpet?

39.a: He makes his nest in high places, and his home on the peaks of the cliffs.
39.q: Where does the eagle make his nest and his home?

40.a: Job put his hand over his mouth.
40.q: How did Job do to show that he was too insignificant to answer Yahweh?

40.a: Yahweh answered Job from out of a fierce storm.
40.q: From what did Yahweh answer Job?

40.a: He told Job to gird up his loins like a man.
40.q: What did Yahweh tell Job to do to prepare to answer Yahweh?

40.a: He said Job condemned Yahweh so that Job could claim he was right.
40.q: Why did Yahweh say that Job was condemning Yahweh?

40.a: He challenges Job to cloth himself with glory, dignity, honor and majesty.
40.q: With what does Yahweh challenge Job to clothe himself?

40.a: Yahweh tells Job to trample them down where they stand.
40.q: What does Yahweh tell Job to do to the wicked people?

40.a: He eats grass like an ox.
His tail is like a cedar.
40.q: What is the tail of the behemoth like?

40.a: Only God can defeat the behemoth.
He lies under the lotus plants in the shelter of the reeds.
He does not tremble and he is confident.
40.q: What does the behemoth think when the river floods and the Jordan surges?

41.a: Yahweh asks Job if he can draw out the leviathan with a fishhook.
41.q: With what does Yahweh ask Job if he can draw out leviathan?

41.a: He asks Job if the fishermen would bargain for leviathan or divide him up to trade among the merchants.
41.q: What does Yahweh ask Job if the fishermen would do with leviathan?

41.a: It someone puts his hand on the leviathan just once, he will remember the battle and do it no more.
41.q: What will happens if a person puts his hand on leviathan?

41.a: No one dares to stir leviathan up, so there is no one who can stand before Yahweh.
41.q: Since no one is fierce enough to dare stir leviathan up, can anyone stand before Yahweh?

41.a: He says it is the doors of his face that are ringed with his teeth, which are a terror.
41.q: How more does Yahweh describe leviathan's mouth?

41.a: One is so near to another that no air can come between them.
41.q: How close are the scales on the back of leviathan?

41.a: His eyes are like eyelids of the morning.
41.q: How does Yahweh say leviathan's eyes are like?

41.a: Out of leviathan's mouth go burning torches, and sparks of fire leap out.
41.q: What comes out of leviathan's mouth?

41.a: It is like a boiling pot on a fire that has been fanned to be very hot.
41.q: How is the smoke from leviathan's nostrils like?

41.a: His heart is as hard as a lower millstone.
They become afraid and draw back.
41.q: What do the gods do when leviathan raises himself up?
What happens when a sword, spear, arrow or any pointed weapon strikes leviathan?

41.a: He thinks of iron as if it were straw and bronze as if it were rotten.
41.q: What does leviathan think of iron and bronze?

41.a: He leaves a spreading trail in the mud as if he were a threshing sledge.
41.q: What kind of trail does leviathan leave?

41.a: He makes the deep to foam up like a boiling pot of water.
41.q: What does he make the deep to do?

41.a: He s has been made to live without fear.
41.q: Why does leviathan have no equal on earth?

42.a: He had spoken things that he did not understand, things too difficult for him to understand, which he did not know about.
42.q: What did Job acknowledge that he had spoken?

42.a: Job despised himself and repented in dust and ashes.
42.q: How did Job respond to Yahweh after seeing him with his eye?

42.a: They had not said right things about Yahweh, as Job had done.
42.q: What did Yahweh say that Eliphaz and his two friends had done wrong?

42.a: He told Eliphaz to take seven bulls and seven rams to offer for themselves as a burnt offering.
42.q: What did Yahweh tell Eliphaz to give as an offering?

42.a: Yahweh said he would accept Job's prayer.
42.q: Whose prayer did Yahweh say he would accept?

42.a: Yahweh restored his fortunes, and gave him twice of what he had possessed before.
42.q: What happened after Job prayed for his friends?

42.a: They each gave him a piece of silver and a ring of gold.
42.q: What did every person give to Job when they came to comfort him?

42.a: Yahweh blessed Job more than the first part of Job's life.
42.q: How did Yahweh bless Job at the end of his life?

42.a: He had seven sons and three daughters.
42.q: How many more sons and daughters did Yahweh give to Job?

42.a: There were no woman in the land as beautiful as Job's daughters, and he gave them an inheritance with their brothers.
42.q: What was unique about Job's daughters?
